Even though people may think that a guidline of their attack would make the game too "easy", it does not. If you were faced with even a normal BAM (Big A** Monsters) in the late game (for example Teraliths or Orisks) and you did not know what sort of attack they were going to do after their eyes glow red, there is a high chance that your health bar WILL deplete, possibly even from 100% to 0 with how strong BAMs get.As for the EnMasse version of TERA. 												TL;DR, Full review beneath this.An over all good mmo with enjoyable dungeons and questing as a buffer, not too hard so can be played casually and satisfying combat that plays more dynamicly than your typical mmo clone, it has a more annoying late game with tedious travelling, slow mounts and a lack luster crafting system. For the price of FREE you can't really go wrong and kind of owe it to yourself to give the game a shot with some friends and see if you can get a few good times out of it.FULL REVIEW:Please bear with me, this is going to be a long one!I probably joined Tera a bit late in the cycle but still found myself enjoying the game, it has all the qualities of your typical MMORPG without sacrificing much for the free to play model.Pro's and cons;Pro's:- As far as I can tell the game is not pay to win.- The game is not particularly hard, many parts of the game (because I am a loser without friends) you can solo.- The game can be challenging at times, especially if you encounter a boss earlier than intended, but bosses are so far doable. (Note that this speaks of the dungeons, I have not raided yet).- Graphics aren't half bad for an mmo, rather cheery but willing to throw in dark themes.- Interesting, uniquely defined area's, in the first 3 area's in the first continent you encounter a desert a forest and a plain.- Sound is good, quiet, yet not inaudible and adds subtle atmosphere.- levelling is relatively fast so that you do not find yourself becoming bored of an area. (a week of gameplay and I am 61)- Dungeon bosses are enguaging and make frequent use of the AOE circle to signify an attack, this makes detecting aggro and dodging powerful shots easier and more fun.- Gives you a mount at level 11, I don't care if it is a bad mount, it's a mount and saves you a ton of time.- Brokerage the place where you rip o- *AHEM* sell your unwanted goods to other players.- Combat is more dynamic that games like WOW where you stand still and just press buttons, Tera expects you to react to combat.- Unique roster of races and classes.Cons;- Getting better weapons from bosses is pointless since relics make better weapons that can be enchanted +9 and early game this is not viable for found weponry.- Crafting disables any other actions what so ever other than to look at more crafting recipe's, it does not even allow you to look at the different crafting fields (crafting in alchemy while looking at armoursmithing is not allowed, why?).- Crafting is tedious and can be completed by just refining materials unless you want to go artisan or 500.- No tutorial or explanation on how to craft.- Yup, still on crafting, there isn't any 'functional' use of recipe's at lower levels since you probably won't know that crafting exists if you are new and even if you did notice it by pressing random buttons (like I did) it is likely that the gear that you could make would not be very useful or in any way 'good'.- Travelling is inconvenient. You cannot fly from the western side of the map to the eastern, we are on dragons and pegasus' but you're telling me that we can't cross continents?- Again with the inconvenient travelling, mounts are scarce to come by and appear largely in the auction or as timed exclusives. This makes travelling inconvenient as mounts have a static speed and the only way to travel quicker is to have a better mount.- Dungeon queing is questionable, its rather haphazard as to whether you will find a que or not within the next 5 minutes.- Quests are actually not bad at all. It is here because some may dislike them, there is an excess of kill quests rinse repeat for the majority of the game, the bread and butter, those who don't enjoy the combat will hate the sheer amount of it.- So much to do, so over levelled. I found myself clearing oxstagarth at the right level, yet abundantly over-levelled in pretty much every area prior.- Dungeons give a ton of experience, so much that you don't actually play dungeons much more than 3 times. This leaves a lot of cool dungeons unplayed and ignored unless its solo'd.- Levelling is really quick, to the point that if you want to join and make a few friends while you are here you will be lucky to find a few since they will most likely out level you or vica versa without a few days gameplay, even my 4 friends that jumped on to join me play Tera had issues remaining the same level, right now we are 60,60,61,62. This might not seem  a lot but is a massive difference when you realise that we have played essentially the same time for the past week.- For some, race specific classes might be an issue, for me its not but for some it will be a big thing.- No magic DPS specific class other than the sorcerer and the mystic. There is no alternative for a high dps damage over time tick sorcerer like a warlock in WOW (A personal gripe).Final thoughts;Tera is a very enjoyable game, it can take up a large chunk of your time if you have some friends who are willing to play with you and you take the time to wait for stragglers (sorry guys!) Much of the eastern continent can be completed quickly and you can level just as fast if not faster, this makes getting to the end game content that much quicker. Dungeons are enjoyable and well paced, the real meat of the game in my opinion, bosses are hard but able to be beaten and some have little tricks to finishing them faster (cannons). Travelling is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥most of the time and really boring but can act as a good time to take a break from questing and dungeoning.The biggest gripe that I have with the game is with the crafting, it's so basic and almost irrelevant by the time that you discover it, and to that end I feel sorry for it. 												Don't mind the hours: I've been a player since its transition to f2p and I played pretty much everything until the expansion hit, so while I miss the latest content I know a good chunk of it.So is the game worth? Yes, even though it is clunky at times.The game is said to be action and is partially true, as you have to physically dodge attacks by moving or using skills that lets you dodge attacks, which forces the players (especially tanks like me) to remember skill patterns in order to dodge or block at the same time (It's easier now with telegraphs, but back then I had to watch the movements with my own eyes!). So it is action but a very stiff kind of action: you can't always attack while moving for instance and many of your attacks requires you to stand still and "aim" before attacking: if you're a lancer and you're charging, you have to line up your shot or you'll miss it. In this case I'd say that the best action kind of playstyle remains Wildstar, where you can freely attack and move without any issues, while TERA is still similar to older mmorpgs where you still have to stand still most of the time. But hey at least there's no tab targetting!Secondly the game is still holding up with its graphics but back in the day it had quite a poor performance: even with my stronger pc I still get lags now and then, forcing me to tone down the parameters. Granted I don't have a super duper overlclocked pc BUT I can run most games at a fairly stable FPS. TERA is very sloppy on this case.The classes are well varied (especially the older ones) and the game has a trinity system with tanks (4 tanks, with berseker being one at cap level unless it got changed), healers (only 2 so far) and various dps. All classes can do one role at once (Excluding Warriors and Bersekers, who can do dps and tank) and they allow some customization in terms of Glyphs, which essentialy boosts some skills for some additional effects: they're not major but enough to help in your role, so if you're a Warrior Tank you'll most likely boost your defense stance and so on.Dungeons are fairly fun, even though at high level it's not uncommon to end up with dps who can outaggro you if you're a very weak tank, and in general tanks are used for keeping enemies at bay while dps will smash them with multi-million damaging attacks. Afterall they can all dodge attacks so it's not impossible, HOWEVER I found the later dungeons (when i played) to be so-so, while the levelling ones seemed better and overall more fun. Also they tend to have daily locks so be careful.And let's face it, I'm delaying the inevitable, which is the fact that this version I'm playing is from Gameforge and while I still play this rather than the NA version, I want to specify a few things that will encourage you to either play the EU or NA version.So is the NA version better than EU? Yes....but there are sacrifices to be made, and one of them is the latency.TERA has never been a very smooth game, even when I started playing, and lag can literally kill you if you're not very careful, as lag can delay your attacks or parry or even dodges most of the time. I played the Na version long ago and I couldn't manage to play for much longer because my attacks had at least a 1-3 seconds delay each (And I have a 100mpb connection!). In addition, the obvious issue with community (no not that it's bad, although I haven't found a single good community in any mmorpg to begin with): NA servers are obviously far behind us in terms of timezone, with nearly 6 to 9 hours of difference between us and them, which means that if you decide to play seriously you'll be forced to stay awake late at night for your endgame content OR hope for some people to raid at your time, who are early morning raids or such. This can affect the gameplay because you will alone most of the day, for only during the night to be somewhat filled with people, and be able to do most content ONLY during late night. As someone who played a few games on US servers in various games (FFXIV, WS, BNS, WoW) for various reason (Mostly in terms of roleplay, which is absent in european servers), it is really a hindrance to be unable to do most content JUST because you're hours forward.And last but not least, the cash shop is definitely better than the EU version, with cheaper prices and a tera sub that actually IS worth the price...however considering that it's mostly cosmetic, the only thing that you would even care about is the bank slots and character slots (which is account bound and will work on every character) and while expensive in the EU version ( 20 euros vs 5 dollars), after that you're pretty much "done": everything else isn't really required and unlike SWTOR, where even skill bars are locked, everything else is pretty much free. So yes the shop is expensive, but only a bunch of things are actually worth spending on: the rest is easily skippable (and while I can't speak for most players, since that I have the limited edition, a friend of mine said that he was fine with only 2 slots and didn't need others)So, is the game worth it? Yes, and it's free so why not trying?Is the EU version better or worse than US? It's worse, undeniably worse, however if you have issues like I did or simply don't like to swap accounts like me, then this is your only choice.But as it is, for what I experienced, the game is worth so I'm giving a thumbs up!

												After playing this game for roughly 4-5 years I can honestly say it's my go to MMO. My main is a reaper which I like the rotations and skills used, it's a class I find more unique then most other games online. At 1st I had a lot grps complaining about my dmg and my rotations and I actually thought I was playing my class properly. Truthfully though, I did some research, looked up the skills and rotations and found out that other players were correct and I was actually a terrible reaper.But after sometime, research and putting skills in the correct area of the tool bar, I got better, much better. The game itself in all the years it's been around has improved in some areas, considering how it used to be when I 1st started to now, you can see the developers put sometime into it and made things for the better in TERA. Admittedly it is from gameforge which a lot of gamers are not fans of and honestly neither am I, if for example you look at the differences between aion and TERA in terms of enchanting gear and weapons. In both cases if you grind dungeons and dailies for gear and once you have it, certain items are required to enchant said gear. With Aion you could enchant your gear and if unsuccessful you could either go down a level on enchanting or lose your gear altogether, which I thought was a kick in the teeth to all gamers and the frustration it brings.With Tera you can enchant gear or weapons and if you fail, you don't lose anything. It actually gives you a slight chance of improvement the next time until your successful which I feel doesn't make the gamers feel bad about failing as there is always a chance of success.From lvl 1-65 it's all about getting to know your class, the rotations, how to get better at it and learning instances along the way. Once hitting 65 the true end game starts which is a constant grind (if you like it) for items and gear to make your  character stronger and more reliable in end game instances. Everything is a learning curve even at end game, watching videos and reading guides, watching bosses for their mechanics and when to hit and dodge at the right time which is essential instead of literally going in all guns blazing. It's trial and error really. Once I got my gear to max level I only then went to instances for even better gear and drops when I felt I was ready and then constantly grinded dungeons to learn them better to become a more reliable person.No person is perfect at their class and even if they say and believe they are, there's always a possibility of a run not going smoothly but if you watch and learn any player can get good at any instance if they put the effort in. The classes are as follows if this game sounds of interest to you:Lancer (Tank)Brawler (Tank/dps)Warrior (tank/dps)ArcherBerzerkerGunnerNinjaReaperMysticPriestApart from PVE content there is also PVP if that's your prefered choice which gives the game a good balance. It's actually nice to play a game and do whatever you like to do unlike aion in comparrison in where if you wanted to do PVE there's always a chance being constantly ganked by players who can flat out kill you when all you want to do is your daily quests which believe me is frustrating, where as with TERA you actually have that option of wanting to openly pvp or not.I honestly don't pvp because I see no point to it, I suck at it and it's not what I play tera for, but if pvp is what you prefer then this game has it.Cons:Since there's a huge amount of classes to try it can get tiresome or perhaps even boring starting from lv 1 all over again, going through the storyline just to get to 65 and learning the class as you go and since I have like 8 chars it does feel kinda boring. On the flipside you've got the experience for all the dungeons you've already learnt and doing them wont be a problem if you understand each class. Cash shop: Yes there is a cash shop and most ppl have said it feels like Pay 2 win. Yes you can buy certain mounts and items and you can sell them via auction house the only downside is that for all the extra incentives and bonuses that come with the game is that if you want to play the game in it's full entirity you need a monthly subscription fee which admittedly makes the game a lot easier on players which comes with daily bonuses, a free mount, instant teleportation to any area and xp/gold buffs to help level up your character much quicker and putting items to sell in the auction house costs nothing where as without the pack, the higher the price you want to sell something for, the more ingame gold it costs you.All in all, it's not a perfect game. I do enjoy it a lot as it constantly rewards players in certain ways to keep playing where as some other games do not. The community is friendly and yes there is the occassional percentage of players that you may end up not wanting to group with again because of their attitudes or how they treat others, but thankfully there's always the option of blocking and never having to work with them again. If there was anything I would improve in this game, it would be the end game enchanting system.Normal weapons and gear go from +1-12, vision maker gear can go from +12 to +15.Vision maker is gear that you grind dungeons for items and then craft, you enchant to +12 and then after comes awakening which costs roughly 800-100 mwa which is quite a lot but the game DOES some events from time to time to make it cheaper, say roughly 200 mwa to awaken.Now the biggest gripe is getting it +13-15. From this point on it's all RNG based and yes I've seen players get it done in 3 tries, I've even talked to ppl who have spent literally thousands of MWA, for example for myself I spent literally 5k mwa before it even went to +13.If I had a choice I'd implement a system which doesnt cheat players out off all their hardwork. You could spend 2 months grinding all that mwa to have a shot to get it +13 and higher only to fail and that can cause a lot of rage and wanting players to quit because of it.So if it was me the system I'd use is this:+13 = 1k mwa+14= 2k mwa+15= 3k mwaIF this system was in place, gamers could actually have something to really work for instead of constantly farming and failing and would give players the incentive to log in daily, grind and continue to play. Not just try and hope for the best, fail and then just quit.But that's just me

												TL;DR: Great and engaging combat, super beautiful world, varied areas. Bad optimization for performance. Has its flaws but is in my opinion the best F2P MMO out there. Despite being F2P, there's no P2W.LONG VERSION:+ The combat is absolutely great. I've played tons of MMOs and most are relatively boring, yet TERA is speedy and fluid, and a game where you have to aim your abilities (no tab-targeting) and use i-frames etc.+ Plenty of classes and playable races to choose from. All of the classes are available to everyone. (Albeit with some restrictions, as I will mention later).+ Despite being F2P, there is no pay to win (P2W) to speak of. You have a cash shop for cosmetics and some things for convenience/extra goodies but that's it.+ The art style is great for characters, monsters, and building designs alike - along with the colour palette utilized throughout. (As subjective as this is).+ The world/area design is great: lots of huge zones to explore, with each of them feeling distinctive and different, but with all of them feeling really "deep". You feel a desire to explore.+ Enough customizability to be interesting for builds and characters, but without being too cluttered or being filled with useless skills/customizations. Gear and other secondary features are also done well.+ Decent in-game music with a lot of ambiental vibes for some appropriate areas, as well as some more triumphant, ethereal, etc. sounds. Certainly pretty good!+ Easy to get started out with generous loot drops and some parcels to help newbies out in the early game.+ Engaging hard content at the very top. (Although hit and miss with the learning curve and how everything BUT the endgame-endgame feels easy to rather easy).+ Great cosmetics. Also, eyecandy in general. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)+/- Main story line is hit and miss.+/- The usual gearing treadmill for endgame, as well as daily quests for reputation and stuff. You know what I mean, so you'll either like it or hate it - or simply live with it and do it anyway!+/- Ease of leveling. Some people hate leveling - I love it, and it makes me feel invested. TERA brings people to level cap incredibly fast, which is great for endgame and alts.+/- As great as the world is, it feels a little meaningless to have it, aside from immersion and when you level up (via quests). A lot of the absolutely beautiful zones are left to just exist with no purpose.- The optimization of the game for performance. By far the worst aspect of this game. You can optimize the game a little better by yourself which is worth it (Google). You could run this with a NASA-tier rig and still have minor issues, though. Still, runs ok at max graphics.- Race/gender locked classes. Stupid idea. (Brawler, Gunner, Ninja and Reaper are female-only - and for certain races).- Mediocre at best UI. Looks ok when tweaked to your preferences, but could use some refinement.- Laggy sound at times during cutscenes, as well as sound not matching up that well with what happens on screen (for cutscenes).- Lack of instructions in a coherent manner in the game (for new people). People might not realize crafting even exists in the game until they butterfinger some key to open a relevant menu.- Mediocre crafting system. There are profits to be had from crafting, but everything feels a little clunky and inaccessible.- Lack of meaningful and well-rounded content. Good endgame-content exists, but there are not many minigames, no open world mob hunting on a regular basis, and a lot of the open world is rendered useless.- Low skill floor (early game spoonfeeding) yet a high skill ceiling creates a weird rift between facerolling and difficulty walls. No real midcore content as of now.- Minor things such as not having Fishing in the game, or personal housing. (Subjective gripes). Also, RNG elements with upgrading gear might discourage some people (I'm ok with it).OVERALL: 8/10, would recommend for MMO-enthusiasts. Despite the very high score, I don't think this game has much cross-appeal to people who hate MMOs, but RPG-fans of action combat can still digg this a lot.

												I used to play this game quite a lot when it turned into F2P several years ago, and now that it's on Steam, I decided to write this review from my experiences.Gonna keep this as short as possible:TERA can be fun to play in small dosages, but on the long run it just feels empty and hollow.The only real problem I have with this game is that there are only 2 free character slots, so you have to pay huge amount of money if you want to make more that 2 characters. This leads to yet another problem, that there are no alternative specialations/roles for the classes, so you mostly have just one way to play the game on each class.The game looks okay-ish on todays standards, while the sounds could use more work, especially on the cutscenes where the sounds don't match what's happening on the screen  (laggy sounds).The most interesting part in this game is its gameplay mechanics.The game's combat uses a real-time battle system that incorporates third-person camera view. The player targets an enemy with a cross-hair cursor rather than clicking or tabbing an individual opponent, which is called the "Non-Target battle system" by the developer. The Players need to actively dodge enemy attacks.[8] A keyboard and mouse or a control pad can be used to control the character.There are total of 7 races that you can play as and total of 12 different classes (though 4 of the newest classes are race and gender locked classes, which is kinda lame). Pros:+ Free to Play+ Leveling new characters is much more faster than it used to be+ Interesting gameplay mechanics+ 12 different classes (but again, you can only play 2 of them for free)+ Lots and lots of Cosmetic items to make your character look unique+ Fun dungeons and raids+ Fun to play on small dosages(+ Lots of eye candy)Cons:- Free to play. Only 2 free character slots- No alternative specs/roles for classes, so there's no variation to your gameplay unless you don't try out different classes (but again, you can only make 2 free characters)- Race and gender locked classes  (only the 4 newest classes though)- Enormous but empty world- Weak and unbalanced PvP  (just my opinion though, I never liked doing PvP in MMORPGs)- Low playerbase- Performance/stuttering issues even on high end PC- Cosmetic items are really, really expensive on both real money and in-game money- Idiotic cosmetic Smart boxes (rng boxes), so even with that high price they have, you cannot even buy those specific cosmetic items that you want, so you have to trust in your luck. My advise is: dont waste your real money on them.Do I recommend:It's an free MMORPG game, so if you're into those, you could give it a try. Otherwise, don't waste your time (or money) on this. In my opinion, TERA is one of the best "F2P MMORPGs" out there.Verdict: 5.5 / 10 - Slightly above average game(1 = do-not-buy game5 = average game10 = must own game)

Just buy stuffs with lower asking price than a normal merchant price and you can get money with it. Not too much, but in the most games I've never seen this possibility and it's good. :) You can try to buy stuffs on lower price with negotiation, and you can buy without the broker fees, which is definitely a nice stuff, and only works when the seller is online.- Steam version's login system: I hate to enter my password at every single login, but with Steam integration it will log you in without asking password, which is really nice for me. (You can link your account to Steam, so no need to create a new one, your existing account will be able to use.)- Leveling: It's really nice and funny with friends even if sometimes it's boring to run and talk with NPCs 10x to get the quest finished. The environment makes it nice and the dungeons are various too, so if you're playing the game first, the leveling won't be boring.- Real money features are buyable with gold: You can find them on trade broker or ask in chat if someone wanna get gold and can buy it for you for real money and change it for gold. This is like new character slots, bank tabs, mounts, pets, skins, etc., you can find them on trade broker too, so if you have enough gold no need to ask just buy it.CONS:- Loot and party system together: If you wanna hit a mob/boss, you need to be in party with the others because only one person will get the loot. I've played a lot of other MMOs and noticed this only in TERA. Maybe there are more games, but for me it's much better if you can get loot with everyone even if you're not in the party. And why? Because you have to ask for party always, and if you're fighting with a mob and would be nice to have some help, others will skip the mob and you, because they can't get anything for it, and most of them won't help you for nothing.- Crystals: It needs money to always use the right crystals and they broke if you die, basically it wouldn't be a bad idea if it wouldn't broke after die. It won't kill the game and you can get enough crystals, but personally I hate this part.- Travelling system: You can buy scrolls, but if you don't have them the travelling is boring after a while. If you're in a town and wanna go to another one which is in another region you have to go to the capital of your region, travel to the other region's capital and after that travel to the other town. And you have to watch the pegasus flying animation which is nice and beautiful but after a while will be boring. You can skip that with scrolls but would be cool to have a system to travel from town to town (for the same price) with just clicking on the map and no need to buy scrolls or fly by pegasus. With Tera Club system you can use Village Atlas to travel faster, but it costs money of course to be a Club Member. :)AFTER LVL 65In the engame you can enchant your equipment and go to dungeons for better ones. The game has some battlegrounds, wich are solo or team pvp games, my favorite is Corsairs' Stronghold where you need to attack and defend 20v20. The dungeon system will pair you with the right classes so you will have healer, tank, dps, and you can farm the stuffs. You can earn gold from daily quests and zone quest, and if you wanna earn achievements you need to repeat dungeons and battlegrounds a lot.This isn't pro or con, but I don't like the achievement and unlock system, because you need to unlock then on every single characters. I know it's in other MMOs too, so not TERA's own system, but you need to buy mounts, or unlock them for every single characters. It makes you to play with your main character the most because there you will have the most unlocked stuffs and mounts. Again, it's not a pro or con, I just write down what I think about the game, and you can think about it otherwise. :)And finally I miss the Steam achievements which could make the whole thing funnier, because you can unlock the achievements with any character and wouldn't neccessary to unlock them with all characters.

												I used to play this game quite a lot when it turned into F2P several years ago, and now that it's on Steam, I decided to write this review from my experiences.Gonna keep this as short as possible:TERA can be fun to play in small dosages, but on the long run it just feels empty and hollow.The only real problem I have with this game is that there are only 2 free character slots, so you have to pay huge amount of money if you want to make more that 2 characters. This leads to yet another problem, that there are no alternative specialations/roles for the classes, so you mostly have just one way to play the game on each class.The game looks okay-ish on todays standards, while the sounds could use more work, especially on the cutscenes where the sounds don't match what's happening on the screen  (laggy sounds).The most interesting part in this game is its gameplay mechanics.The game's combat uses a real-time battle system that incorporates third-person camera view. The player targets an enemy with a cross-hair cursor rather than clicking or tabbing an individual opponent, which is called the "Non-Target battle system" by the developer. The Players need to actively dodge enemy attacks.[8] A keyboard and mouse or a control pad can be used to control the character.There are total of 7 races that you can play as and total of 12 different classes (though 4 of the newest classes are race and gender locked classes, which is kinda lame). Pros:+ Free to Play+ Leveling new characters is much more faster than it used to be+ Interesting gameplay mechanics+ 12 different classes (but again, you can only play 2 of them for free)+ Lots and lots of Cosmetic items to make your character look unique+ Fun dungeons and raids+ Fun to play on small dosages(+ Lots of eye candy)Cons:- Free to play. Only 2 free character slots- No alternative specs/roles for classes, so there's no variation to your gameplay unless you don't try out different classes (but again, you can only make 2 free characters)- Race and gender locked classes  (only the 4 newest classes though)- Enormous but empty world- Weak and unbalanced PvP  (just my opinion though, I never liked doing PvP in MMORPGs)- Low playerbase- Performance/stuttering issues even on high end PC- Cosmetic items are really, really expensive on both real money and in-game money- Idiotic cosmetic Smart boxes (rng boxes), so even with that high price they have, you cannot even buy those specific cosmetic items that you want, so you have to trust in your luck. My advise is: dont waste your real money on them.Do I recommend:It's an free MMORPG game, so if you're into those, you could give it a try. Otherwise, don't waste your time (or money) on this. In my opinion, TERA is one of the best "F2P MMORPGs" out there.Verdict: 5.5 / 10 - Slightly above average game(1 = do-not-buy game5 = average game10 = must own game)

												TL;DR: Great and engaging combat, super beautiful world, varied areas. Bad optimization for performance. Has its flaws but is in my opinion the best F2P MMO out there. Despite being F2P, there's no P2W.LONG VERSION:+ The combat is absolutely great. I've played tons of MMOs and most are relatively boring, yet TERA is speedy and fluid, and a game where you have to aim your abilities (no tab-targeting) and use i-frames etc.+ Plenty of classes and playable races to choose from. All of the classes are available to everyone. (Albeit with some restrictions, as I will mention later).+ Despite being F2P, there is no pay to win (P2W) to speak of. You have a cash shop for cosmetics and some things for convenience/extra goodies but that's it.+ The art style is great for characters, monsters, and building designs alike - along with the colour palette utilized throughout. (As subjective as this is).+ The world/area design is great: lots of huge zones to explore, with each of them feeling distinctive and different, but with all of them feeling really "deep". You feel a desire to explore.+ Enough customizability to be interesting for builds and characters, but without being too cluttered or being filled with useless skills/customizations. Gear and other secondary features are also done well.+ Decent in-game music with a lot of ambiental vibes for some appropriate areas, as well as some more triumphant, ethereal, etc. sounds. Certainly pretty good!+ Easy to get started out with generous loot drops and some parcels to help newbies out in the early game.+ Engaging hard content at the very top. (Although hit and miss with the learning curve and how everything BUT the endgame-endgame feels easy to rather easy).+ Great cosmetics. Also, eyecandy in general. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)+/- Main story line is hit and miss.+/- The usual gearing treadmill for endgame, as well as daily quests for reputation and stuff. You know what I mean, so you'll either like it or hate it - or simply live with it and do it anyway!+/- Ease of leveling. Some people hate leveling - I love it, and it makes me feel invested. TERA brings people to level cap incredibly fast, which is great for endgame and alts.+/- As great as the world is, it feels a little meaningless to have it, aside from immersion and when you level up (via quests). A lot of the absolutely beautiful zones are left to just exist with no purpose.- The optimization of the game for performance. By far the worst aspect of this game. You can optimize the game a little better by yourself which is worth it (Google). You could run this with a NASA-tier rig and still have minor issues, though. Still, runs ok at max graphics.- Race/gender locked classes. Stupid idea. (Brawler, Gunner, Ninja and Reaper are female-only - and for certain races).- Mediocre at best UI. Looks ok when tweaked to your preferences, but could use some refinement.- Laggy sound at times during cutscenes, as well as sound not matching up that well with what happens on screen (for cutscenes).- Lack of instructions in a coherent manner in the game (for new people). People might not realize crafting even exists in the game until they butterfinger some key to open a relevant menu.- Mediocre crafting system. There are profits to be had from crafting, but everything feels a little clunky and inaccessible.- Lack of meaningful and well-rounded content. Good endgame-content exists, but there are not many minigames, no open world mob hunting on a regular basis, and a lot of the open world is rendered useless.- Low skill floor (early game spoonfeeding) yet a high skill ceiling creates a weird rift between facerolling and difficulty walls. No real midcore content as of now.- Minor things such as not having Fishing in the game, or personal housing. (Subjective gripes). Also, RNG elements with upgrading gear might discourage some people (I'm ok with it).OVERALL: 8/10, would recommend for MMO-enthusiasts. Despite the very high score, I don't think this game has much cross-appeal to people who hate MMOs, but RPG-fans of action combat can still digg this a lot.
